examples: She left the kitchen door ajar so the cat could come and go.
The window was slightly ajar, letting in a cool night breeze.
He noticed the cookie jar lid was ajar and knew his sister had taken one.
Through the ajar curtains, she could see the twinkling city lights.
The book was left ajar on the table, marking the page he had finished reading.

entries.meaning: to choose by voting. To appoint, nominate or pick.
examples: Our class will elect a new student representative next week.
The citizens gathered in the town hall to elect their new mayor.
They decided to elect the most experienced climber as their team leader.
It is a great privilege to be old enough to elect leaders for your country.
She was elected captain of the netball team by her teammates.
The ballerina made an elegant leap across the stage.
She wore an elegant gown to the formal dinner party.
The swan, with its long, curved neck, is a very elegant bird.
He admired the elegant handwriting in his grandmother's old letters.
The room was decorated with elegant furniture and beautiful paintings.

entries.meaning: to walk slowly. To stroll or amble.
examples: On the sunny afternoon, they decided to saunter through the park.
The happy winner began to saunter across the stage to collect his prize.
With plenty of time to spare, he chose to saunter home instead of rushing.
We watched the cats saunter lazily along the garden wall.
They would often saunter down to the pier to watch the boats.

entries.meaning: to disfigure, twist, bend out of shape.
examples: The acrobat had to contort her body to fit inside the tiny box.
His face would contort with frustration when he couldn't solve the puzzle.
The strong winds made the young trees contort and bend over.
The artist used heat to contort the plastic into a new, strange shape.
It was amazing to watch the gymnast contort herself into a human pretzel.

entries.meaning: to dig up, make a hole in the ground.
examples: Archaeologists began to excavate the ruins of the ancient Roman fort.
The construction crew used a large digger to excavate the site for the new building.
My dog loves to excavate the garden in search of his buried bones.
They had to excavate a deep trench to lay the new water pipes.
Scientists travelled to the desert to excavate dinosaur fossils.

entries.meaning: hard work, move around with difficulty
examples: After a long day of toil in the garden, he was ready for a good rest.
Building the treehouse was hard toil, but it was worth it in the end.
The story was about the toil and struggles of miners from a hundred years ago.
She knew that success in her exams would require many hours of toil.
Despite the toil of the long journey, they were happy to reach the campsite.

entries.meaning: a commotion or confused noise. Chatter.
examples: There was a great hubbub in the classroom when the teacher announced a surprise trip.
I couldn't hear what my friend was saying over the hubbub of the crowded market.
The birds created a hubbub of chirping in the trees early in the morning.
"What's all the hubbub about?" asked the librarian, looking over her glasses.
The sudden power cut caused a hubbub of confusion throughout the school.
We paddled in the shallow water of the babbling brook.
A small wooden bridge was built to help people cross the brook.
The thirsty deer stopped to take a drink from the clear, cold brook.
You can follow the brook as it meanders through the forest.
We collected smooth, flat stones from the bottom of the brook.
The old soldier shared stories about his adventures with his army comrade.
He and his closest comrade started a band together.
The two friends were true comrades, always helping each other out.
A good comrade is someone you can trust and rely on.
The explorers and their local guides became firm comrades on the long expedition.
It is very important to be punctual for your lessons at school.
The train is always punctual, arriving at the station at exactly the right time.
Sarah is a very punctual person who hates being late for anything.
He set his alarm early to make sure he was punctual for his job interview.
Being punctual is a good way to show respect for other people's time.
The family's small shop grew into a prosperous business over the years.
The city was a prosperous trading port with ships arriving from all over the world.
They lived in a large house in a prosperous part of town.
The farmer was hoping for a prosperous year with plenty of rain for his crops.
The queen ruled over a peaceful and prosperous kingdom.
Modelling clay is very pliable, so you can shape it into anything you can imagine.
The young willow branches were pliable enough to be woven into a basket.
The gymnast was so pliable that she could easily do the splits.
A good leader needs a pliable mind to adapt to new situations.
The softened leather was pliable and easy to stitch into a wallet.
The shop manager offered a full refund to rectify his mistake.
She wrote a letter of apology to rectify the misunderstanding.
A good mechanic will be able to rectify the problem with your bicycle.
The student was asked to rectify the errors in his homework.
It is important to try and rectify your mistakes whenever you can.
"Welcome to my humble abode!" he said, opening the door to his small flat.
The grand palace was the official abode of the royal family.
A little mud hut was the only abode the villagers had.
A beaver's abode is called a lodge, which it builds from sticks and mud.
They were looking for a new abode closer to the children's school.
The final score of 10-0 was a complete rout for the visiting team.
Our school's quiz team celebrated their rout of their local rivals.
The chess master achieved a quick rout of his opponent in only 15 moves.
The battle ended in a total rout, and the defeated army fled.
The election was a rout, with one candidate winning almost all the votes.
Her vivacious personality made her the life and soul of every party.
The group of vivacious children ran laughing into the playground.
He loved her vivacious spirit and how she was always smiling.
The dance troupe gave a very vivacious performance full of energy.
The vivacious tour guide made the museum trip fun and exciting.
My brother is always the one to instigate silly arguments.
Her funny story was enough to instigate a wave of giggles around the room.
The leaders hoped to instigate a peaceful discussion between the two groups.
It was the students' idea to instigate a campaign to clean up the local park.
The villain in the story tried to instigate a riot in the city.
She has a natural aptitude for playing the piano.
He showed a remarkable aptitude for solving difficult maths problems.
The special test is designed to discover your aptitude for different jobs.
From a young age, it was clear he had an aptitude for sport.
Even with a natural aptitude, you must practise hard to become an expert.
The palace ballroom had an ornate ceiling painted with gold.
She inherited an ornate jewellery box from her grandmother.
The cover of the old book was decorated with an ornate pattern.
They admired the ornate carvings around the grand fireplace.
The wedding cake was an ornate, five-tiered masterpiece.

entries.meaning: to leave or desert someone. Or no fear.
examples: The crew had to abandon the sinking ship.
It is cruel to abandon a pet on the side of the road.
They decided to abandon their plan when they realised it was too dangerous.
The old house had been abandoned for years and was falling into ruin.
She would never abandon her friends in a time of need.
He gave a dubious excuse for being late, and the teacher didn't believe him.
She was dubious about whether the shortcut would actually be any faster.
The "get rich quick" scheme sounded highly dubious to me.
The witness's story was dubious and had several inconsistencies.
That restaurant has a dubious reputation for cleanliness.

entries.meaning: to postpone or a take a temporary break (used in court trials).
examples: The judge decided to adjourn the court trial until the next day.
The meeting was getting late, so they agreed to adjourn and finish the discussion tomorrow.
The debate will adjourn for a short lunch break.
The chairperson will now adjourn the assembly.
Let's adjourn this game of chess and resume it later.
She wore an exquisite diamond necklace to the ball.
The artist was famous for her exquisite paintings of flowers.
The meal was absolutely exquisite; every dish was perfect.
They admired the exquisite craftsmanship of the antique furniture.
The butterfly's wings had an exquisite and delicate pattern.
He painted over the drab, grey walls with a cheerful yellow.
The office was a drab and boring place to work.
She felt her uniform was very drab and wished she could wear something more colourful.
The rainy weather made the whole town look drab and gloomy.
His speech was long and drab, and many people in the audience fell asleep.
The sick old man had a feeble pulse.
She made a feeble attempt to lift the heavy box, but couldn't move it.
His feeble excuse for not doing his homework was not convincing.
The candlelight cast a feeble glow in the dark room.
After being ill for a week, he felt too feeble to get out of bed.
A ferocious lion escaped from the zoo.
The two dogs were locked in a ferocious fight.
A ferocious storm battered the coast with high winds and heavy rain.
The dragon in the story was a ferocious beast that breathed fire.
He had a ferocious temper and would shout at the smallest thing.
We had intermittent rain showers throughout the afternoon.
The Wi-Fi signal is intermittent and keeps cutting out.
He suffers from intermittent pains in his leg.
The car's engine was making an intermittent sputtering sound.
There was intermittent applause during the long, boring play.
The long, monotonous car journey through the desert seemed to go on forever.
Working on the factory assembly line was a monotonous job.
The teacher's monotonous voice made it hard for the students to stay awake.
He was tired of eating the same monotonous meals every day.
The dripping tap made a monotonous sound that kept him from sleeping.

entries.meaning: can be seen through OR easily understood.
examples: Glass is a transparent material.
The water in the mountain stream was crystal clear and transparent.
Her reasons for leaving were transparent; everyone knew she was unhappy.
He's a terrible liar; his excuses are always so transparent.
The politician promised to be transparent and honest with the public.
The steam from the shower made the bathroom mirror opaque.
He couldn't see through the opaque, frosted glass of the window.
The political language in the document was opaque and difficult to understand.
She put up an opaque screen to divide the room into two sections.
The water in the pond was opaque and murky.
He is a very reliable friend; you can always count on him for help.
It's important to get your news from a reliable source.
My car is old but it's very reliable; it always starts.
We need a reliable babysitter to look after the children.
The weather forecast is not always reliable.
She was reluctant to lend her new pen to her careless friend.
He was reluctant to admit that he had made a mistake.
The shy boy was reluctant to go on stage and speak in front of the school.
I am reluctant to spend so much money on a new phone.
The cat was reluctant to go outside in the rain.
After the long hike, the weary travellers finally reached their camp.
She had a weary expression on her face after a long day at work.
I am growing weary of your constant excuses.
The weary soldiers marched for another ten miles.
His voice sounded weary as he told them the bad news.
The plants will thrive in the sunny garden.
The business began to thrive after they launched their new website.
Most children thrive when they are given praise and encouragement.
The small village thrived once the new railway line was built.
Some people thrive on challenges and pressure.
The circus performer walked carefully along the taut rope.
His muscles were taut with effort as he lifted the heavy weights.
The tent's guy ropes were pulled taut to keep it from blowing away.
There was a taut silence in the room as everyone waited for the announcement.
Her face was taut with anxiety as she waited for the doctor's news.
They had an argument over a trivial matter and didn't speak for days.
Don't waste your time on trivial details; focus on the main points.
The celebrity was in the news for some trivial gossip.
It was a trivial error, but it caused the whole computer system to crash.
He felt his problems were trivial compared to what others were going through.

entries.meaning: something that is real or definite, able to be touched.
examples: We need tangible evidence, not just rumours and theories.
The museum had many tangible artifacts from the ancient world.
The police found no tangible proof that he had committed the crime.
The rewards of her hard work were tangible: a promotion and a pay rise.
Love is not a tangible thing that you can hold in your hand.
The shrewd businessman made a fortune by investing in the right companies.
She was a shrewd negotiator and always got a good deal.
He made a shrewd move in the chess game that won him the match.
The shrewd politician knew exactly what to say to win the voters' support.
It was a shrewd decision to buy the house before the prices went up.
Getting a tattoo will leave a permanent mark on your skin.
The accident caused permanent damage to his leg.
She was looking for a permanent job, not just a temporary contract.
The museum's permanent collection is open to the public all year round.
The war brought about permanent changes to the country.
She is a passionate advocate for animal rights.
The group was formed to advocate for better public transport in the city.
Doctors often advocate a healthy diet and regular exercise.
He will advocate on your behalf during the meeting.
The politician was a strong advocate for free school meals for all children.
The lake was still and serene in the early morning light.
She had a serene expression on her face as she listened to the classical music.
They found a serene spot in the woods for their picnic.
He longed for a more serene and peaceful lifestyle.
The yoga class left me feeling calm and serene.
The "for sale" sign was on a vacant plot of land.
Is this seat vacant, or is someone sitting here?
He stared into space with a vacant expression on his face.
There were several vacant properties for rent in the town.
The hotel had no vacant rooms left for the bank holiday weekend.
The customs officers will seize any illegal goods.
You must seize the opportunity while you have the chance.
The eagle swooped down to seize its prey.
The soldiers prepared to seize control of the enemy's fortress.
A sudden wave of panic seemed to seize him.
He was intolerant of anyone who didn't agree with his opinion.
The intolerant ruler punished anyone who practised a different religion.
Many people are intolerant of lactose, a sugar found in milk.
It is important to teach children not to be intolerant of others.
Her intolerant attitude meant that she had very few friends.
A microscope is used to magnify tiny objects so we can see them.
He has a tendency to magnify his problems and make them seem worse than they are.
The small print was difficult to read, so she used a special screen to magnify it.
The sound was magnified by the huge speakers at the concert.
The newspaper story seemed to magnify the importance of the event.
Fishermen use colourful plastic worms to lure fish onto their hooks.
The company tried to lure new customers with special offers and discounts.
The smell of fresh baking was used to lure people into the cake shop.
The pirates tried to lure the ship onto the rocks.
Don't be lured into a false sense of security.
The doctor was concerned about possible internal injuries after the accident.
The company sent an internal memo to all its employees.
A turtle has an external shell but its organs are all internal.
The building's internal structure was damaged by the fire.
The police have started an internal investigation into the officer's conduct.
The exterior walls of the house needed a fresh coat of paint.
The car's tough exterior protected the driver during the crash.
Don't judge a book by its exterior; the story inside might be amazing.
He seems grumpy on the exterior, but he is actually very kind.
The castle's exterior was grey and imposing.

entries.meaning: to knock something down. Destroy, wreck.
examples: The old, unsafe factory is going to be demolished next week.
Our team managed to demolish the opposition, winning the game 50-0.
I was so hungry I managed to demolish the entire pizza by myself.
The earthquake was powerful enough to demolish several buildings.
They plan to demolish the old warehouse and build new flats.
The eccentric old lady lived in a house shaped like a teapot.
He was known for his eccentric behaviour, like wearing a top hat everywhere he went.
My eccentric aunt collects garden gnomes and has hundreds of them.
The artist was a brilliant but eccentric character.
His fashion sense was a little eccentric, but always interesting.

entries.meaning: In a bad mood. Cross or irritable
examples: The baby is always cranky when she is tired.
My dad gets cranky if he doesn't have his morning coffee.
I felt cranky and out of sorts after a long, difficult day.
"Don't be so cranky!" she said to her complaining brother.
The cranky old man shouted at the children to get off his lawn.
The scientists all concur that climate change is a serious issue.
"A brilliant idea," he said, "I fully concur."
The committee must concur on the new proposal before it can be actioned.
Do you concur with the verdict in this case?
My sister and I rarely concur on which film to watch.
The contented cat purred loudly as she stroked its fur.
He gave a contented sigh as he relaxed into the warm bath.
She felt contented with her simple life in the countryside.
The baby looked full and contented after his feed.
They were a contented couple, happy in each other's company.
The new skyscraper was a colossal building that dominated the skyline.
It took a colossal effort from the whole team to finish the project on time.
The ancient Egyptians built colossal pyramids in the desert.
Winning the lottery was a colossal piece of luck.
The movie was a colossal failure and lost millions of pounds.
The museum had an authentic dinosaur skeleton on display.
Experts confirmed that the painting was an authentic Van Gogh.
The restaurant served authentic Italian food, just like in Rome.
She gave an authentic account of what had happened during the robbery.
The document was sealed with an authentic wax stamp.
He had broad shoulders from years of swimming.
The new road was broad enough for four lanes of traffic.
She has a broad knowledge of history from her years of study.
They sailed their boat across the broad expanse of the lake.
There is broad agreement among scientists about the cause of the disease.
Is your salary adequate to support your family?
Make sure you have an adequate supply of food and water for your camping trip.
His performance in the exam was adequate, but not brilliant.
The small hotel room was adequate for a one-night stay.
A five-minute speech is not adequate to explain such a complex topic.
She was adamant that she had not done anything wrong.
He was adamant about his decision and refused to change his mind.
The teacher was adamant that all homework must be handed in on time.
Despite the evidence, the suspect remained adamant that he was innocent.
My parents are adamant that I must finish my vegetables before I can have dessert.
She was late for school for three consecutive days.
The team celebrated their fifth consecutive win.
5, 6, and 7 are consecutive numbers.
He served two consecutive terms as prime minister.
It rained for ten consecutive hours without stopping.

entries.meaning: a beginner, a novice. Does not accept money to participate.
examples: The race is open to both amateur and professional athletes.
He's an amateur photographer, but his pictures are amazing.
The play was performed by a local group of amateur actors.
An amateur is someone who does something for the love of it, not for money.
She may be an amateur, but she has a lot of natural talent.

entries.meaning: Someone who has an occupation they are paid to do. An expert.
examples: You should hire a professional plumber to fix that leak.
She behaved in a very calm and professional manner during the emergency.
He is a professional musician who plays the violin in an orchestra.
The footballer was suspended for his unprofessional conduct on the pitch.
It is important to maintain a professional attitude at work.
The scientists examined the minute particles of dust under the microscope.
There were minute traces of poison found in the victim's blood.
She pointed out a minute crack in the teacup.
Despite his minute size, the ant was able to carry a large crumb.
The details in the model village were minute and incredibly realistic.
The word 'road' is often abbreviated to 'Rd.' in street names.
Can you abbreviate your story to fit into the space provided?
'Mister' is abbreviated as 'Mr.'.
In text messages, people often abbreviate words to save time.
The teacher asked the students not to abbreviate words in their formal essays.
The captured spy refused to confess his secrets.
After hours of questioning, the thief finally decided to confess.
I must confess, I'm not a big fan of horror movies.
She confessed to her friend that she had broken the vase.
The little boy had chocolate all over his face, so he had to confess to eating the cake.
The company was found to be negligent in the way it handled its customers' data.
It was negligent of him to leave the gate open, allowing the dog to escape.
The report concluded that the accident was caused by a negligent driver.
The negligent babysitter was watching TV instead of the children.
He was accused of being negligent in his duties as a security guard.
Can you condense this 10-page report into a one-page summary?
When steam cools, it will condense back into water.
The author was asked to condense his book for the new paperback edition.
Condensed milk is much thicker and sweeter than regular milk.
She has a talent for being able to condense complex ideas into simple explanations.

entries.meaning: something that is compulsory (has to be done).
examples: It is mandatory for all passengers on a plane to wear a seatbelt during takeoff.
Wearing a helmet while riding a motorbike is mandatory in many countries.
Attending the safety briefing is mandatory for all new employees.
The school has a mandatory uniform policy.
He was sentenced to a mandatory life sentence for the crime.

entries.meaning: something that is possible, believable, logical
examples: She gave a plausible explanation for why she was late.
The police didn't think the suspect's alibi was very plausible.
It is plausible that the dinosaurs were wiped out by a giant asteroid.
The science fiction film presented a plausible vision of the future.
He tried to think of a plausible excuse for not having his homework.

entries.meaning: to forbid, not allow, to restict.
examples: The rules prohibit students from using their phones in class.
Smoking is strictly prohibited inside the building.
The law prohibits the sale of alcohol to people under the age of 18.
My parents prohibit me from staying out late on school nights.
The sign on the gate was intended to prohibit entry to the private land.
The company made a huge profit in its first year of business.
She sold her old car for a small profit.
The main aim of a business is to maximise its profit.
They donated all the profit from the charity event to a local hospital.
There is no profit in arguing with him; you will never change his mind.

entries.meaning: To approve, confirm or endorse something.
examples: The treaty must be ratified by all the participating countries.
The union members voted to ratify the new pay agreement.
The new school rules need to be ratified by the board of governors.
Parliament will meet tomorrow to ratify the proposed legislation.
Until the contract is ratified, it is not legally binding.

entries.meaning: to prove someone wrong. Contradict, oppose.
examples: The scientist conducted an experiment to refute the old theory.
She produced evidence that completely refuted the accusations against her.
It is difficult to refute his argument because he has so much data to support it.
The lawyer's job was to refute the claims made by the prosecution.
He issued a statement to refute the rumours that had been spreading in the media.
I always feel sluggish and tired on Monday mornings.
The hot weather made everyone feel sluggish.
The economy has been sluggish for the past year, with very little growth.
The large meal made him feel sluggish and sleepy.
The snail moved at a sluggish pace across the path.
Do you have sufficient food for all your guests?
10 should be sufficient to buy your lunch.
He didn't get sufficient sleep last night and felt tired all day.
The police did not have sufficient evidence to charge him with the crime.
One hour is not sufficient to complete this difficult exam.
The valiant knight charged towards the fire-breathing dragon.
The firefighters made a valiant effort to save the burning building.
The soldiers were praised for their valiant defence of the city.
Despite a valiant attempt, our team lost the match in the final minute.
The story tells the tale of a valiant prince who rescues a princess.

entries.meaning: something you do instinctively, naturally, automatically without thinking
examples: They made a spontaneous decision to go to the beach for the day.
The audience broke into spontaneous applause at the end of the amazing performance.
He is a very spontaneous person, always coming up with fun, last-minute ideas.
Her joke caused a moment of spontaneous laughter in the serious meeting.
A social movement is rarely a spontaneous event; it is usually planned.
The company will deduct tax from your salary each month.
For every question you get wrong, they will deduct one point from your score.
The shop will deduct the value of the voucher from your total bill.
Don't forget to deduct the cost of your expenses from your income.
You can deduct the deposit you already paid from the final amount.
It was very considerate of you to ask how I was feeling.
He is a considerate host who always makes sure his guests are comfortable.
Please be considerate of our neighbours and don't make too much noise.
She gave her considerate attention to the student's problem.
A considerate person thinks about the feelings and needs of others.
You should dilute the fruit juice with water before giving it to a baby.
The strong cleaning fluid must be diluted before you use it.
He tried to dilute the bright yellow paint by adding some white.
The politician's message was diluted after he tried to please everyone.
Adding too much ice will dilute your drink.

entries.meaning: to be rude, direct to the point
examples: He gave a terse, one-word answer to my long question.
The manager's email was terse and to the point.
She can be very terse when she is busy.
His terse reply made it clear that he was not in the mood to chat.
A terse message is short and can sometimes seem rude.

entries.meaning: to say something nice to someone. To show your approval.
examples: It is always nice to receive a compliment on your work.
She paid him a compliment on his new haircut.
He is always quick to compliment others on their achievements.
"You're a great cook," is a lovely compliment to receive.
The best compliments are the ones that are genuine and sincere.

entries.meaning: a person or thing that is unimportant.
examples: He felt like a nonentity in his new school where he didn't know anyone.
The famous actor was surrounded by photographers, while his assistant was treated like a nonentity.
Before she became a star, she was a complete nonentity.
The king treated the peasants as if they were nonentities.
The report dismissed the small protest group as a political nonentity.

entries.meaning: stuck in your ways, refusing to change an opinion.
examples: The obstinate donkey refused to move another step.
He is the most obstinate person I have ever met; he will never change his mind.
She can be very obstinate when she thinks she is right.
The stain was obstinate and would not wash out of the shirt.
His obstinate refusal to compromise made negotiations very difficult.
Climbing Mount Everest is an arduous and dangerous task.
It was an arduous journey through the dense jungle.
She had the arduous job of cleaning the entire house by herself.
After an arduous day of training, the athlete was exhausted.
The students were given the arduous task of memorising a long poem.
The climbers prepared for their ascent of the mountain.
The hot air balloon made a slow and graceful ascent into the sky.
Her rapid ascent to the position of CEO was very impressive.
The first part of the walk is a steep ascent up the hill.
The plane began its final ascent before reaching cruising altitude.
The weather in Britain is notoriously variable; one minute it's sunny, the next it's raining.
The quality of the food at that restaurant is very variable.
The interest rate on the loan is variable, meaning it could go up or down.
In mathematics, 'x' is often used to represent a variable quantity.
The success of the project is dependent on several variable factors.

entries.meaning: to spread out over a large area. To split up and go in different directions
examples: The police used tear gas to disperse the crowd of protesters.
When the teacher arrived, the group of students quickly dispersed.
The dandelion seeds were dispersed by the wind.
The fog began to disperse as the sun came out.
The aid workers helped to disperse food and water to the refugees.
The lift began to descend to the ground floor.
They watched the sun descend below the horizon.
The climbers had to be careful as they began to descend the treacherous mountain.
A feeling of calm descended over the room.
The family is descended from a long line of Scottish kings.
He was an amiable man, well-liked by everyone who met him.
She had an amiable smile that put everyone at ease.
Our amiable host made us feel very welcome in his home.
Despite the difficult situation, they managed to have an amiable conversation.
The two rival captains had an amiable chat before the match started.
During the long, cold winter, she would yearn for the warmth of summer.
The homesick student began to yearn for his family and friends.
He would often yearn for the simple, carefree days of his childhood.
After weeks at sea, the sailors yearned to be back on dry land.
The exiled prince yearned to return to his kingdom.
They spent a languid afternoon lounging by the pool.
The hot weather made him feel languid and sleepy.
She gave a languid wave of her hand to say goodbye.
The cat stretched out in a languid manner in the patch of sun.
The river flowed at a languid pace through the peaceful countryside.

entries.meaning: start something, set something in order.
examples: The company plans to initiate a new training programme for its employees.
It was my friend who had to initiate the conversation, because I was too shy.
The government will initiate an inquiry into the cause of the disaster.
He was formally initiated into the secret society.
Who initiated the argument between the two friends?

entries.meaning: very dry. Very little or no moisture.
examples: Cacti are plants that are well-suited to living in an arid climate.
The Atacama Desert is one of the most arid places on Earth.
After weeks without rain, the ground was arid and cracked.
The conversation was rather arid and uninteresting.
They had to travel for days across the arid landscape.

entries.meaning: something that is about to happen.
examples: The dark clouds suggested that a storm was imminent.
The soldiers were preparing for an imminent attack.
When the fire alarm went off, everyone knew that danger was imminent.
He was very nervous about his imminent exams.
The public was warned of the imminent threat of a volcanic eruption.

entries.meaning: second from last. Last but one.
examples: The penultimate chapter of the book was the most exciting one.
He fell over on the penultimate hurdle and lost the race.
This is the penultimate episode of the series; the finale is next week.
My birthday is on the penultimate day of the month.
The runner was in second place as they entered the penultimate lap.
A rusty nail was protruding from the old piece of wood.
He was so thin that his ribs seemed to protrude from his chest.
Her bottom lip would protrude when she was about to cry.
The balcony protrudes from the front of the building.
Be careful not to trip over the tree roots that protrude from the path.
The coffee had gone cold and was now just tepid.
He splashed his face with tepid water from the basin.
The bathwater was tepid and not very relaxing.
The new film received a tepid reception from the critics.
She gave a tepid smile, showing she was not very enthusiastic.

entries.meaning: to keep something to use in the future. To store something
examples: Squirrels hoard nuts to eat during the winter.

Which aisle are the biscuits in at the supermarket?
The usher will show you to your seat in the theatre aisle.
I prefer to have an aisle seat on a plane so I can get up easily.
The aisles in the library were lined with tall bookshelves.
The government took action to bolster the economy.
He used some extra pillows to bolster his back while he was sitting up in bed.
The team's confidence was bolstered by their recent victory.
More evidence is needed to bolster your argument.
The good news helped to bolster her spirits.
The treasure was buried on a remote, deserted isle.
The Isle of Wight is a popular holiday destination off the south coast of England.
An isle is another word for an island, especially a small one.
They took a ferry to the beautiful isle to spend the day there.
The story was set on a mysterious isle in the middle of the ocean.

entries.meaning: a bold or daring plan. Showing lack of respect.
examples: The robbers planned an audacious heist to steal the crown jewels.
It was an audacious plan, but it just might work.
The young entrepreneur made an audacious bid to buy the much larger company.
He is an audacious climber who is not afraid to take risks.
She made the audacious claim that she was the best player in the world.
He is an ardent supporter of his local football team and goes to every match.
She has an ardent desire to become a famous singer.
They are ardent believers in the power of positive thinking.
An ardent fan is someone who shows great enthusiasm for something.
He was an ardent admirer of the artist's work.
The link between the two events is tenuous and may just be a coincidence.
He has a tenuous grasp of the subject and is likely to fail the exam.
The climbers held on to the tenuous rope, hoping it would not break.
The plot of the film was rather tenuous and hard to believe.
Her claim to the throne was tenuous and not supported by many people.
The millionaire lived an opulent lifestyle with a huge mansion and many sports cars.
The palace was decorated in an opulent style with gold and marble everywhere.
They enjoyed an opulent meal at the most expensive restaurant in town.
The film portrayed the opulent world of the super-rich.
She wore an opulent diamond necklace that must have cost a fortune.

entries.meaning: able to float. Happy or light-hearted
examples: A rubber duck is buoyant and will float in the bath.
The boat was made from a buoyant material that would not sink.
She was in a buoyant mood after hearing the good news.
Despite the team's recent losses, the manager remained buoyant and optimistic.
The economy is buoyant, with house prices and employment both rising.

entries.meaning: a thin sheet of metal to wrap food OR to prevent/frustrate someone from succeeding or doing something.
examples: The police managed to foil the robbers' plan to steal the diamonds. (Verb)
She wrapped the sandwiches in aluminium foil to keep them fresh. (Noun)
The hero's attempt to save the world was foiled by the cunning villain. (Verb)
In stories, a "foil" character is one who contrasts with the main character. (Noun)
His plans were foiled at the last minute by an unexpected event. (Verb)
The mother began to croon a lullaby to her sleepy baby.
The singer was famous for his smooth voice and his ability to croon romantic songs.
To croon is to sing or hum in a soft, low voice.
He would often croon to himself as he worked in the garden.
The old records were full of famous crooners from the 1950s.

entries.meaning: not correct, false or not recognised OR a disabled person
examples: Your passport is out of date, so it is invalid for travel. (Adjective)
The old woman was an invalid and had to be cared for by a nurse. (Noun)
The computer gave an error message saying "invalid parameters requested". (Adjective)
The argument was based on invalid reasoning and was therefore incorrect. (Adjective)
Because he forgot to sign the cheque, it was invalid. (Adjective)
The flamboyant pop star was famous for his outrageous costumes.
He has a very flamboyant personality and loves being the centre of attention.
The peacock spread its flamboyant tail feathers.
The building was designed in a flamboyant style with lots of decoration.
She waved her hands in a flamboyant gesture.
The car has dual controls, so both the instructor and the learner can drive it.
She has dual nationality; she is a citizen of both Britain and America.
The new phone has a dual camera system for taking better photos.
The film explored the dual nature of the main character, who was both good and evil.
This room serves a dual purpose as a study and a guest bedroom.

entries.meaning: a contest between two foes-to settle an argument.
examples: In the old days, men would fight a duel to settle an argument.
The two knights faced each other in a formal duel with swords.
The two rival politicians were locked in a verbal duel during the debate.
A duel is a contest between two people to settle a point of honour.
He challenged his enemy to a duel at dawn.
We may need to modify the design to reduce the cost.
You can modify the settings to suit your personal preferences.
The original plan has been modified slightly.
He had to modify his car so that it could be driven by a disabled person.
A chameleon can modify the colour of its skin to blend in with its surroundings.
The invitation stated that the dress code was formal attire.
The bride's wedding attire was a beautiful white gown.
Attire is a word for clothes, especially of a formal or special type.
The company's employees are all required to wear business attire.
The knights were dressed in their full battle attire.
She was tired of his perpetual complaining.
The country lived in a state of perpetual fear of war.
A perpetual motion machine is a machine that can run forever without any external energy.
The bottom of the deep ocean is in a state of perpetual darkness.
He seemed to have a perpetual smile on his face.

entries.meaning: tiredness (extreme) OR a weakness in metal caused by stresses.
examples: She was suffering from fatigue after studying all night for her exam.
The long journey caused him to suffer from extreme fatigue.
Fatigue can be dangerous when you are driving.
A common symptom of the illness is fatigue and muscle weakness.
Metal fatigue can cause weaknesses in a metal structure.
The little boy was contrite after he broke the window and apologised immediately.
She wrote a contrite letter of apology to her friend.
The defendant seemed genuinely contrite for his actions.
A contrite person is someone who feels very sorry and guilty for something they have done.
He had a contrite expression on his face as he confessed his mistake.

entries.meaning: urge of force someone to do something. To move something forward.
examples: His sense of duty impelled him to report the crime.
The strong winds impelled the ship towards the rocks.
A feeling of hunger impelled him to search for food.
To impel someone is to force or urge them to do something.
What was it that impelled you to become a doctor?

entries.meaning: friendly and outgoing OR a sugary drink.
examples: The two leaders had a cordial and productive meeting.
We received a cordial welcome from our hosts.
Despite their political differences, they maintained a cordial relationship.
A cordial is also a type of sweet, sugary drink.
He is a cordial man who is always pleasant to be around.
Their relationship was based on a web of deceit and lies.
He used deceit to trick the old woman into giving him her money.
Deceit is the act of misleading someone or hiding the truth.
She was accused of practising deceit to get what she wanted.
Honesty is always better than deceit in the long run.

entries.meaning: someone with total power (in a bad way).
examples: The country was ruled by a brutal dictator for many years.
A dictator is a ruler who has total power and often rules in a cruel way.
The people rose up in rebellion against the hated dictator.
My boss is a bit of a dictator; he always has to have things his own way.
The dictator's regime was known for its human rights abuses.

entries.meaning: at fault, deserving blame, responsible for action.
examples: The court found him culpable for the accident and ordered him to pay damages.
If you are culpable, you are deserving of blame for something wrong.
Both drivers were found to be equally culpable for the crash.
He was held culpable for the company's financial losses.
The negligent parent was considered culpable for the child's injuries.

entries.meaning: a difficult task, requiring hard work.
examples: She found the task of caring for her elderly parents increasingly onerous.
The government imposed an onerous new tax on small businesses.
An onerous duty is one that is difficult and burdensome to perform.
He had the onerous responsibility of organising the entire event by himself.
Filling out all the paperwork was an onerous but necessary job.
The two small companies decided to amalgamate to form one larger company.
The new curriculum will amalgamate history and geography into a single subject.
To amalgamate is to combine or unite to form one organisation or structure.
The different tribes agreed to amalgamate to fight their common enemy.
The recipe says you should amalgamate all the dry ingredients first.
The security guard remained vigilant throughout the night.
You must be vigilant for pickpockets in crowded tourist areas.
A vigilant parent keeps a close watch on their children when they are playing.
The soldiers kept a vigilant eye on the enemy's movements.
Being vigilant is an important part of staying safe.

entries.meaning: say something aloud so someone can write down. Giving bossy instructions.
examples: The teacher will dictate a list of spelling words for the students to write down.
My boss is not allowed to dictate how I spend my time outside of work.
She dictated a letter to her personal assistant.
Don't let other people dictate your choices in life.
The terms of the peace treaty were dictated by the victorious army.

entries.meaning: funny or trying to be funny (usually at an inappropriate time).
examples: He was being facetious when he said he was going to quit his job and join the circus.
It was a facetious remark, but she took it seriously and was offended.
A facetious person is someone who tries to be funny, often at an inappropriate time.
I was just being facetious; please don't take what I said to heart.
His facetious comments were not appreciated during the serious meeting.

entries.meaning: a figure of speech comparing something to another think. ie as light as a feather, as blind as a bat.
examples: "As brave as a lion" is a simile that compares someone's bravery to a lion's.
A simile is a figure of speech that compares two different things using the words "like" or "as".
The poet used a beautiful simile to describe the sunset.
"He is as strong as an ox" is another common simile.
Can you think of a simile to describe how cold the weather is?

entries.meaning: able to speak more than one language.
examples: She is bilingual in English and Spanish.
Being bilingual can be a great advantage when you are looking for a job.
He grew up in a bilingual household, speaking both French and German.
A bilingual person is someone who is able to speak two languages fluently.
The school has a bilingual education programme for its students.

entries.meaning: a person who causes problems. An enemy or adversary.
examples: In the story, the main antagonist is the hero's evil twin brother.
An antagonist is a person who opposes or is hostile to someone or something.
The protagonist is the main character in a story, while the antagonist is their main opponent.
He has been a vocal antagonist of the government's new policy.
The two politicians were old antagonists who had been rivals for many years.

entries.meaning: to get rid of something, to destroy something
examples: Scientists are working to find a cure that will eradicate the deadly disease.
The government has promised to eradicate poverty in the country.
We need to eradicate this invasive weed from our garden before it spreads further.
To eradicate something is to destroy it completely.
The campaign aims to eradicate illiteracy by providing free books for all children.

entries.meaning: a list of special (technical) words with definitions in a book.
examples: The textbook included a glossary at the back to explain all the technical terms.
A glossary is an alphabetical list of words with their meanings.
If you don't understand a word, you can look it up in the glossary.
The glossary was very helpful for understanding the difficult legal document.
This book has a glossary of musical terms.

entries.meaning: to force a person out of their position.
examples: The company's board of directors voted to oust the unpopular CEO.
The rebels tried to oust the dictator from power.
He was ousted from his position as team captain after they lost ten games in a row.
To oust someone is to force them out of a job or position of power.
The opposition party is hoping to oust the current government in the next election.

entries.meaning: acting in a fair and reasonable manner.
examples: The company is committed to the equitable treatment of all its employees.
The parents tried to find an equitable solution that would be fair to both of their children.
An equitable society is one where everyone has a fair chance to succeed.
The judge's decision was seen as equitable and just.
They agreed to an equitable distribution of the profits.
The doctor recommended a programme of vigorous exercise to improve his health.
The team put up a vigorous defence and managed to win the game.
He is a vigorous and healthy man, despite his age.
The police have launched a vigorous investigation into the crime.
She gave the dusty carpet a vigorous shake.

entries.meaning: a task requiring a lot of effort and time.
examples: Digging the new pond by hand was a long and laborious task.
The students were given the laborious job of copying out the entire book.
It was a laborious process, but the final result was worth all the effort.
A laborious task is one that requires a lot of time and effort.
Before computers, writing a book was a much more laborious process.
Al Capone was a notorious gangster in the 1920s.
The road is notorious for being an accident blackspot.
He is a notorious liar, so you can't trust anything he says.
A notorious person is someone who is famous for something bad.
The notorious pirate was feared by sailors all over the world.
The abandoned house had an eerie atmosphere that made us feel scared.
There was an eerie silence in the forest at night.
He heard an eerie cry coming from the misty graveyard.
The strange music had an eerie and unsettling quality.
An eerie green light was glowing in the sky.

entries.meaning: distance around an object or shape.
examples: To find the perimeter of a shape, you need to add up the lengths of all its sides.
The soldiers set up a guard post on the perimeter of the army base.
The police formed a cordon around the perimeter of the crime scene.
The perimeter of the garden was marked by a tall wooden fence.
They walked the perimeter of the park, a distance of about three miles.

entries.meaning: ability to do a task, skilled.
examples: She is a highly competent surgeon who is very good at her job.
We need to hire a competent mechanic to fix the car.
He is not very competent at DIY; he always makes a mess.
A competent student should be able to pass this exam easily.
It is important to have a competent and experienced pilot flying the plane.

entries.meaning: moisture in air falling to the ground: rain, sleet, snow, hail.
examples: Rain, snow, sleet, and hail are all forms of precipitation.
The weather forecast is for heavy precipitation tomorrow.
Precipitation is a key part of the Earth's water cycle.
The annual precipitation in this region is very low, which is why it is a desert.
The plants get all the water they need from natural precipitation.
His official residence is at 10 Downing Street.
The grand country house was the family's summer residence.
Please state your name, age, and place of residence.
A residence is a place where someone lives.
He took up residence in a small flat in the city centre.
The lithe dancer moved gracefully across the stage.
A cat is a very lithe animal that can move with great agility.
The gymnast had a lithe and slender body.
A lithe person is thin, supple, and graceful.
She had the lithe movements of a young ballet dancer.

entries.meaning: a figure of speech where an object is described as something else because it resembles the object. ie the cloud is cotton wool, you are my sunshine.
examples: "The classroom was a zoo" is a metaphor that suggests the classroom was chaotic and noisy.
A metaphor is a figure of speech where a word or phrase is applied to something it doesn't literally apply to.
In the metaphor "all the world's a stage", the world is compared to a theatre stage.
A simile uses "like" or "as", but a metaphor says something *is* something else.

He tried to goad his rival into a fight by insulting him.
She was goaded into action by the unfair criticism.
Don't let him goad you into losing your temper.
To goad someone is to provoke or annoy them to stimulate an action or reaction.

entries.meaning: to "wind someone up. To cause someone to be hostile.
examples: Try not to antagonize your little brother, or he'll start crying.
His constant teasing was meant to antagonize his classmates.
Don't antagonize the wild animal; it might attack.
She felt antagonized by his rude comments and decided to leave.

entries.meaning: over confidence. Exaggerated sense of own importance.
examples: The arrogant young man believed he was better than everyone else.

An arrogant person often shows a rude sense of self-importance.

entries.meaning: a return, the amount of produce made (agricultural). To give way under force.
examples: Drivers must yield to oncoming traffic at the junction. (Verb)

The farmer was happy with the high yield of his corn crop. (Noun)

The bond has a high yield, meaning it pays a good return on investment. (Noun)

entries.meaning: a good, moral or ethical person. A person of good standing.
examples: She was admired for her virtuous character and kind heart.

The country was going through a turbulent period of political unrest.
The ocean was turbulent with high waves and strong winds.

She had a turbulent relationship with her elder sister.

entries.meaning: the belief in only one way
examples: The newspaper article showed a clear bias towards one political party.
It is important for a judge to show no bias in a court case.

Climbing a mountain is a very strenuous activity.

It was a strenuous day of revision before the final exam.
The football fans became very rowdy after their team won the championship.

A rowdy crowd gathered outside the concert venue.
He was thrown out of the pub for being too rowdy.
We could hear the sounds of a rowdy party coming from next door.
The scrawny cat looked like it hadn't eaten in days.
He was a scrawny child who often got picked on by bullies.

You need to eat more if you don't want to be so scrawny.
She looked scrawny and unwell after her long illness.

entries.meaning: early, responsive. A cue, a hint
examples: She is always prompt in replying to emails. (Adjective)

entries.meaning: bright, luminous or happy in appearance.
examples: The bride looked radiant in her white wedding dress.

The smell of the rotten food was absolutely repulsive.

She is always optimistic, even when things are going badly.
I am optimistic that we will find a solution to this problem.
An optimistic person always looks on the bright side of life.
The doctor gave an optimistic prognosis for his recovery.
Despite the challenges, he remained optimistic about the future.
The dark, ominous clouds gathered on the horizon, threatening a storm.
There was an ominous silence in the house after the argument.
The villain in the film gave an ominous laugh.
An ominous sign is one that suggests something bad is going to happen.
He received an ominous warning from an anonymous source.
Obesity is becoming increasingly prevalent in many countries.
The belief that Friday the 13th is unlucky is prevalent in some cultures.
The disease is more prevalent in older people.
Smartphones are now prevalent everywhere you look.

entries.meaning: to upset, to annoy, to offend
examples: His loud chewing really started to irritate me.
The new medicine might irritate your skin; if it does, stop using it.
Don't irritate the cat, or it might scratch you.
Her constant questions began to irritate him.
The harsh chemicals can irritate your eyes and throat.
The stress of the job was driving him insane.
It would be insane to try and swim across the ocean.
The villain in the movie had an insane desire for power.
His idea sounded completely insane, but it actually worked.
Some of his theories are so bizarre they sound insane.
It is imperative that we find a solution to climate change immediately.
Good communication is imperative for a successful team.
It is absolutely imperative that you are on time for the meeting.

The survival of the species makes it imperative to protect its habitat.
He was morose after losing his job and didn't want to talk to anyone.
The weather was as morose as his mood.
She sat in the corner, looking morose and refusing to join in the fun.
A morose expression was fixed on his face.
The news filled him with a morose sense of despair.
The refugees had to survive on a meagre ration of food each day.
He earned a meagre salary that barely covered his living expenses.
The plant struggled to grow in the meagre soil.
Her performance in the exam was rather meagre, and she barely passed.
The evidence against him was so meagre that the case was dismissed.
His immature behavior at the dinner party embarrassed his parents.
The young bird was still too immature to fly long distances.
It was an immature decision to quit the team just because he lost one game.
Although he is twenty, he still has a very immature sense of humor.
The fruit is still immature and will need another week to ripen.
Many people remain ignorant of the new laws passed by the government.

He was completely ignorant of the fact that a surprise party was being planned for him.
She didn't mean to be rude; she was just ignorant of the local customs.
We cannot afford to remain ignorant about the effects of pollution on our planet.
The hotel room was immaculate, with not a speck of dust to be found.
She kept her garden in immaculate condition, spending hours every day weeding it.
His white shirt remained immaculate even after a long day at the office.
The athlete's performance was immaculate, earning him a perfect score from the judges.
After the renovation, the old house looked immaculate and brand new.
The machinery stood idle in the factory during the workers' strike.
It is not good to sit idle all day when there is so much work to be done.
They spent the long summer afternoon in idle conversation by the river.
An idle mind is said to be the devil's playground.
The car's engine was left to idle while he ran into the shop.
The jubilant fans rushed onto the pitch when their team won the championship.
She was jubilant after receiving the news that she had passed her exams with flying colors.
The city was filled with jubilant crowds celebrating the end of the war.
He felt jubilant when he finally reached the summit of the mountain.
A jubilant atmosphere filled the room as the lottery winner was announced.

entries.meaning: awful, ghastly, or having an unhealthy interest in death
examples: He has a morbid fascination with horror movies and ghost stories.
The old cemetery had a morbid atmosphere in the thick morning fog.
It's not healthy to dwell on such morbid thoughts all the time.
The news report gave a morbid account of the tragic accident.
She found his jokes about illness to be rather morbid and unfunny.
The doctor advised him to take a moderate amount of exercise every day.
We had a week of moderate weather, with neither too much sun nor rain.
He holds moderate political views and prefers compromise to conflict.
The hotel was of a moderate price, making it affordable for families.
You should try to consume sugar in moderate quantities for a balanced diet.

entries.meaning: not bothered, indifferent, appearing calm and relaxed
examples: He gave a nonchalant shrug when asked why he was late for class.
Despite the pressure of the exam, she remained remarkably nonchalant.
He walked into the room with a nonchalant air, as if nothing had happened.
She tried to appear nonchalant, but her hands were shaking with nerves.
His nonchalant attitude towards his chores frustrated his parents.
He shook hands with his opponent after the long tennis match.
The boxer studied his opponent's previous fights to find a weakness.
She is a formidable opponent in any debate.
The political candidate was respectful when speaking about his opponent.
We must respect our opponents, even if we are determined to beat them.

entries.meaning: the ability to wait or endure delay without getting upset
examples: Teaching young children requires a great deal of patience.
You need to have patience if you want to become a successful gardener.
He lost his patience after waiting in the queue for over an hour.
With a bit of patience, we will eventually find the answer to the puzzle.
She showed great patience as she explained the rules of the game again.
The extra revision sessions are optional, but most students choose to attend.
You can add extra toppings to your pizza, but they are optional and cost more.
Wearing a tie at this event is optional, so you can dress casually if you prefer.
The insurance on the rental car is optional, but it's often a good idea to have it.
Some parts of the form are optional and can be left blank.
The doctor visited every patient in the ward during his morning rounds.
The patient was told to rest for a week after the operation.
Nurses work hard to ensure that every patient is comfortable and well-cared for.
The new hospital has enough beds for over five hundred patients.
It is important to respect the privacy of every patient in the clinic.
It is wrong to be prejudiced against people based on where they come from.
The judge was accused of being prejudiced and was asked to step down from the case.
He realized that his prejudiced views were based on false information.
We must strive to create a society where nobody feels prejudiced against.
An umpire must never be prejudiced towards one team or the other.

entries.meaning: a noise or commotion OR a bat for tennis
examples: The children were making such a racket in the garden that the neighbors complained.
He broke his tennis racket in frustration after losing the final set.
I couldn't sleep at all last night because of the racket coming from the party next door.
You need a sturdy racket if you want to play squash properly.
What's all that racket going on in the kitchen?

entries.meaning: happening before the proper time, early
examples: The baby was premature and had to stay in the hospital for several weeks.
It would be premature to celebrate our victory before the final results are in.
The heavy frost caused the premature death of many garden plants.
His premature retirement from football was due to a serious knee injury.
I think it's a bit premature to decide on a holiday destination in January.

entries.meaning: the peak, highest point, or pinnacle
examples: The sun reaches its zenith at midday when it is highest in the sky.
At the zenith of her career, she was the most famous singer in the world.
The Roman Empire reached its zenith during the second century AD.
For many athletes, winning an Olympic gold medal is the zenith of their achievements.
The mountain climbers were exhausted but happy when they reached the zenith.

entries.meaning: pushy, assertive, or ready to attack
examples: The dog became aggressive whenever a stranger approached the gate.
He has an aggressive management style that some employees find intimidating.
The team played an aggressive game, determined to score as many goals as possible.
You should try to be assertive without being overly aggressive.
The aggressive salesman wouldn't take "no" for an answer.

entries.meaning: empty, unproductive, or unable to produce life
examples: The explorers struggled to find water in the barren desert.

The moon is a barren landscape with no air or water.
It was a barren season for the striker, who failed to score a single goal.
Despite the barren surroundings, some small plants managed to survive in the cracks of the rocks.

entries.meaning: having a strong desire to succeed or better oneself
examples: She is an ambitious student who hopes to study medicine at university.
The company has ambitious plans to expand into international markets.
Building a skyscraper in only one year was an ambitious goal.
He is very ambitious and is always looking for ways to get a promotion.
The young artist's most ambitious project was a mural that covered an entire wall.

entries.meaning: to contain, enclose, or restrain within limits
examples: Please confine your comments to the topic we are currently discussing.

The heavy rain meant the children were confined to the house all afternoon.
We must try to confine the spread of the virus to this one area.
He felt confined by the strict rules of the school.
It was apparent to everyone that he was not feeling well.
Her apparent lack of interest in the project was disappointing.

The solution to the problem became apparent after a few minutes of thought.
It is apparent that we need to change our strategy.

entries.meaning: something that is fake, synthetic or man-made
examples: The flowers in the vase were artificial but looked very real.
She avoids foods with artificial colors and flavorings.
The athlete ran on an artificial track.
He used artificial light to grow the plants indoors.
Her smile seemed artificial and forced.

entries.meaning: to stop a task. To discontinue
examples: The factory will cease production at the end of the month.
The rain did not cease all day.
He ordered the soldiers to cease fire immediately.
Wonders will never cease!
The noise from the construction site finally ceased at 5 pm.
The roads are always congested during rush hour.
He had a congested nose and couldn't breathe properly.
The city centre is heavily congested with traffic.
The airways were congested with holiday flights.
I tried to avoid the congested shopping aisles.
The abandoned house stood on a desolate hill.
After the war, the landscape was desolate and ruined.
She felt desolate and alone after her best friend moved away.
The explorers crossed a desolate wasteland of ice and snow.
