The vet's clinic was full of nervous pets and their owners.
They are opening a new health clinic in the village next month.

entries.meaning: the outer line that marks the limit of an area. A dividing line.
examples: The fence marks the boundary between our garden and the park.
The river forms a natural boundary between the two countries.
The explorers crossed the boundary into uncharted territory.
It is important to respect other people's personal boundaries.
The ball went over the boundary line for a six.

entries.meaning: to join in with an activity. To eat and drink.
examples: We were invited to partake in the school's sports day activities.
Visitors are welcome to partake of the refreshments provided.
He refused to partake in the silly argument.
They were happy to partake in the festive celebrations.
She decided to partake in the local community project.
The weather in spring is often very changeable.
Her moods were changeable, making it hard to know how she felt.
Prices in the market are changeable depending on the season.
He has a changeable personality and frequently changes his mind.
The conditions for the race were changeable and difficult.

entries.meaning: a sea-wave caused by an earthquake. The arrival of something totally overwhelming.
examples: The coastal town was devastated by a massive tsunami.
Scientists use sensors to detect the early signs of a tsunami.
After the earthquake, a tsunami warning was issued for the entire region.
The charity received a tsunami of donations following the appeal.
They built a sea wall to protect the village from a potential tsunami.
It is shameful to treat animals with such cruelty.
The politician's behaviour was described as shameful by the media.
It would be shameful to give up now after all our hard work.
He felt shameful about the lie he had told his parents.
The waste of food in this country is absolutely shameful.

entries.meaning: to set something on fire. To light, arouse or inspire.
examples: We used dry twigs to kindle the campfire.
Her stories helped to kindle an interest in history among the children.
The teacher hoped to kindle a love of reading in his students.
The sunset seemed to kindle the clouds with a golden glow.
A chance meeting helped to kindle their old friendship.

entries.meaning: ascertain the size, amount or degree of something. A standard unit.
examples: Please measure the length of the table before we buy the tablecloth.
The tailor needs to measure you for your new suit.
We must take measures to ensure the safety of the children.
It is difficult to measure the success of the project so early on.
The thermometer is used to measure the temperature of the room.

entries.meaning: movement of vehicles, ships, trains, aircraft or people.
examples: We were stuck in heavy traffic for over two hours.
The new bypass was built to reduce traffic in the town centre.
Air traffic controllers manage the movement of planes at the airport.
There is a lot of pedestrian traffic on the high street on Saturdays.
The bridge was closed to all traffic during the storm.

entries.meaning: relating to water. Growing or living in water.
examples: The aquarium has a wonderful display of aquatic plants and animals.
Dolphins are highly intelligent aquatic mammals.
We enjoyed watching the aquatic displays at the water park.
Some insects spend the first part of their lives as aquatic larvae.
Rice is an example of an aquatic crop that grows in flooded fields.

entries.meaning: lack of success. Not meeting a target.
examples: The experiment was a failure, but the scientists learned a lot from it.
He was afraid of failure and didn't want to try anything new.
The engine failure caused the car to stop in the middle of the road.
A failure to follow the rules will result in a punishment.
Despite their best efforts, the mission ended in failure.

entries.meaning: three of something. To multiply by three.
examples: She made a triple jump to win the gold medal.
The company hopes to triple its profits by next year.
He ordered a triple scoop of chocolate ice cream.
The noise was a triple threat to our concentration.
We need to triple the recipe to feed all the guests.

entries.meaning: change a gas or vapour into a liquid. To make something denser. To shorten.
examples: You can see the steam condense on the cold window pane.
The editor asked the author to condense the long novel.
We need to condense the main points of the meeting into a short report.
Adding milk will help to condense the thick soup.
The cold air caused the moisture in the breath to condense.

entries.meaning: a signature. Usually from someone famous.
examples: The fans waited outside the stadium to get the footballer's autograph.
She has a book full of autographs from famous actors.
He was kind enough to sign an autograph for the young boy.
The author signed an autograph on the front page of her new book.
I would love to have an autograph from my favourite singer.

entries.meaning: a follow-up work of art. A film or book that forms the next part of the story.
examples: The fans are eagerly waiting for the sequel to the hit movie.
The second book in the series is a direct sequel to the first one.
Most people thought the sequel was even better than the original film.
The story concludes in the long-awaited sequel.
The director is already planning a sequel to his latest project.

entries.meaning: a long narrow strip of something.
examples: She tied a blue ribbon in her hair.
The gift was wrapped in beautiful paper and tied with a silk ribbon.
The winning horse was decorated with a red ribbon.
A long ribbon of smoke rose from the chimney.
They cut the ribbon to officially open the new school building.

entries.meaning: the study of the physical or natural world through observations or experiments.
examples: Science helps us to understand how the world around us works.
She wants to study science at university and become a doctor.
We performed a fascinating experiment in our science lesson today.
Advances in science have led to many life-saving medical treatments.
Space exploration is one of the most exciting branches of science.

entries.meaning: the point or place where something starts, begins or comes from.
examples: The river has its origin in the high mountains.
Scientists are still researching the origin of the universe.
The word 'vocabulary' has its origin in Latin.
He is proud of his Irish origins.
The custom has its origins in an ancient festival.

entries.meaning: a transparent optical material that either concentrates or disperses light.
examples: The photographer cleaned the lens of his camera before taking the picture.
He needs new lenses for his glasses because his eyesight has changed.
A magnifying glass uses a special lens to make objects look larger.
The telescope has a powerful lens that allows us to see distant stars.
I accidentally scratched the lens of my sunglasses.

entries.meaning: an event that is sudden or striking. Exciting or impressive. Theatrical.
examples: The team scored a dramatic last-minute winner.
There was a dramatic improvement in his grades after he started studying.
The landscape changed dramatically as we drove from the mountains to the coast.
She has a very dramatic way of telling stories.
The play ended with a dramatic and unexpected twist.

entries.meaning: the first version of a piece of writing. To prepare a first version.
examples: I've written a first draft of my essay, but it needs a lot of work.
The architect showed them the draft plans for their new house.
He was asked to draft a letter to the council.
This is just a rough draft; I'll send you the final version tomorrow.
The constitution was drafted by a committee of experts.

entries.meaning: a person who sees an event (usually a crime). To see an event happen.
examples: The police are appealing for any witness to the accident to come forward.
She was called as a witness in the court case.
I was lucky enough to witness the birth of my nephew.
He was the sole witness to the robbery.
The document must be signed in the presence of a witness.

entries.meaning: to protect something/someone. Could be from heat loss, electricity or bad things.
examples: We need to insulate our loft to save money on our heating bills.
The wires were insulated with a rubber coating to prevent electric shocks.
He tried to insulate his children from the harsh realities of the world.
A wetsuit helps to insulate a diver from the cold water.
The flask is designed to insulate the contents and keep them hot.

entries.meaning: Threatening behaviour. The presence of danger.
examples: The dog gave a low, menacing growl.
The dark, menacing clouds warned of an approaching storm.
He had a menacing look in his eyes that frightened her.
The gang of youths looked menacing as they walked towards them.
The silence in the old house was more menacing than any noise.

entries.meaning: Serious, calm and in control. Worthy of respect.
examples: She remained dignified and calm despite the chaos around her.
The old professor had a very dignified and scholarly appearance.
He gave a dignified speech, accepting his defeat with grace.
Even when she was angry, she tried to behave in a dignified manner.
The queen walked with a dignified and royal air.

entries.meaning: a large and impressive building. An official residence (could be royal or a ruler etc).
examples: Buckingham Palace is the official residence of the Queen.
The tour took us through the magnificent state rooms of the palace.
The ancient palace was now a ruin, but you could still see its former glory.
The wealthy sheikh built a modern palace in the desert.
She felt like a princess when she visited the beautiful palace.

entries.meaning: the way in which two or more things are connected. Could be people or objects.
examples: It is important to have a good relationship with your friends and family.
The police are investigating the relationship between the two suspects.
There is a close relationship between poverty and crime.
He has a difficult relationship with his father.
The relationship between the two countries has improved in recent years.

entries.meaning: allowing or accepting what happens without resistance.
examples: He is too passive and lets other people make decisions for him.
She plays a very passive role in the team and rarely gets involved.
Passive smoking can be very harmful to your health.
The passive boy never stood up for himself.
Passive resistance was used to protest against the new law.

entries.meaning: to use up completely. Make someone feel tired. Expel gas or steam.
examples: The long hike up the mountain will exhaust even the fittest climbers.
We must not exhaust our natural resources before we find alternatives.
The car's tailpipe will exhaust harmful gases into the atmosphere.
If you don't take a break, you will exhaust yourself completely.
The athlete gave everything he had until he was exhausted.
He suffered an agonising injury during the football match.
Waiting for the exam results was an agonising experience.
She had to make the agonising decision to put her old dog to sleep.
The last few miles of the marathon were agonising.
He let out an agonising groan of pain.

entries.meaning: The highest, supreme, best. Happens at the end of a process.
examples: The ultimate prize for any footballer is to win the World Cup.
His ultimate ambition is to become a famous actor.
The ultimate decision rests with the manager.
This is the ultimate guide to cooking Italian food.
The ultimate fate of the universe is a mystery.

entries.meaning: the place where something or someone is.
examples: The police are trying to discover the whereabouts of the missing person.
His whereabouts are currently unknown.
Do you know the whereabouts of my keys? I can't find them anywhere.
She was last seen in the whereabouts of the old library.
The tracker allows us to know the whereabouts of the delivery van at all times.
I am very satisfied with the quality of my new phone.
The teacher was not satisfied with his student's work.
He gave a satisfied smile after finishing the delicious meal.
She will not be satisfied until she gets a full refund.
Are you satisfied with the service you have received?

entries.meaning: an elaborated musical composition for an orchestra.
examples: We listened to a beautiful symphony by Mozart at the concert hall.
The orchestra performed Beethoven's famous 5th Symphony.
A symphony is usually composed of four separate movements.
The sound of the birds in the morning was like a symphony of nature.
He is composing a new symphony for the city's orchestra.

entries.meaning: alter or move something slightly. Adapting to a new situation.
examples: You can adjust the height of the chair to make it more comfortable.
It took him a while to adjust to his new school.
The driver had to adjust his mirrors before setting off.
I need to adjust my watch; it's five minutes fast.
She found it hard to adjust to living in a new country.

entries.meaning: decayed material used for fertiliser. To make compost.
examples: We make our own compost from vegetable peelings and grass cuttings.
Mixing compost into the soil will help your plants to grow.
You can buy bags of compost from the garden centre.
It is better for the environment to compost your food waste.
The council has a special collection for garden compost.

entries.meaning: a period of time set aside for an activity. An official meeting.
examples: I have a training session with the football team this evening.
The band booked a recording session at the music studio.
The parliament will hold a special session to debate the new law.
How many sessions of therapy have you had?
After a long study session, he took a well-deserved break.

entries.meaning: Dislike or feeling that a person or thing is worthless. Disrespectful of the law.
examples: He looked at his rival with utter contempt.
She has a deep contempt for people who are cruel to animals.
The politician was held in contempt by the public after the scandal.
He was found guilty of contempt of court for refusing to answer the judge's questions.
They treated his suggestion with contempt and laughed at him.
Can you close the door? There's a cold draught in here.
We sat by the fire to keep warm from the draughty old house.
Draught excluders can help to keep your home warm in winter.
She felt a draught on her back and shivered.
The candle flickered in the draught from the open window.
I perceive a slight change in his attitude towards me.
Cats are able to perceive sounds that humans cannot hear.
How do you perceive the situation?
The new manager was perceived as being too strict.
She is not as confident as she is often perceived to be.
The dog was happily gnawing on a large bone.
The mouse had gnawed a hole in the skirting board.
He would often gnaw his pen when he was thinking.
The problem gnawed at her conscience and she couldn't sleep.
The hungry prisoner started to gnaw on a crust of bread.

entries.meaning: awake and aware of your surroundings.
examples: He was knocked over, but he remained conscious.
She made a conscious decision to eat more healthily.
I became conscious that someone was watching me.
He is very fashion-conscious and always wears the latest styles.
It is important to be conscious of the environment.
The team had to devise a new strategy to win the game.
He devised a clever plan to escape from the prison.
They are trying to devise a way to reduce traffic in the city centre.
The engineer devised a new machine to sort the letters.
She devised a system for keeping her files organised.

entries.meaning: a grain used for food. A breakfast food.
examples: I usually have a bowl of cereal for breakfast.
Wheat, rice, and corn are all types of cereal.
The farmer grows several different cereal crops on his farm.
Many breakfast cereals are fortified with vitamins and minerals.
My favourite cereal is cornflakes with milk and sugar.
He was the victim of a malicious rumour that was intended to ruin his reputation.
The computer was infected with a malicious virus.
She gave him a malicious smile, and he knew she was up to no good.
He was found guilty of malicious damage after he deliberately broke the window.
Don't listen to her; she's just being malicious.

entries.meaning: able to endure (pain etc), fairly good (food etc).
examples: The pain was barely tolerable, but she tried not to complain.
The film was not great, but it was tolerable.
The conditions in the refugee camp were barely tolerable.
I find his arrogance just about tolerable.
The food in the canteen is tolerable, but it's not very exciting.
The country fought for its independence from colonial rule.
Moving away from home gave her a new sense of independence.
Financial independence is very important to many people.
The Declaration of Independence was signed in 1776.
He is a very independent person and doesn't like to ask for help.

entries.meaning: a large group of animals. To move a group of animals.
examples: A herd of cows was grazing peacefully in the field.
We saw a large herd of elephants on our safari trip.
The farmer used his dog to herd the sheep into the pen.
It's not a good idea to just follow the herd; you should think for yourself.
They had to herd the children onto the bus.

entries.meaning: complying with an order or request.
examples: He was a very obedient child and always did what he was told.
My dog is very obedient and comes back when I call him.
The soldiers were expected to be completely obedient to their commanding officer.
The students were not very obedient and a lot of them were misbehaving.
She was an obedient and hardworking employee.
He took a solemn oath to tell the truth in court.
The funeral was a solemn occasion.
She had a solemn expression on her face and didn't smile.
The room was filled with a solemn silence.
The wedding was a solemn and beautiful ceremony.
The birds were singing on the bough of the old apple tree.
He hung a swing from a strong bough.
The wind whistled through the bare boughs of the winter trees.
The cat was stuck on a high bough and couldn't get down.
They decorated the boughs of the Christmas tree with baubles and lights.

entries.meaning: allowing the opinions of others, though not always agreeing.
examples: It is important to be tolerant of people from different cultures and backgrounds.
She is very tolerant of her husband's bad habits.
The teacher was not very tolerant of students who were late.
We need to create a more tolerant and inclusive society.
Some plants are more tolerant of drought than others.
What is your preference: tea or coffee?
He was given preference for the job because he had more experience.
I have a strong preference for classical music over pop music.
The seating arrangements were made according to the guests' preferences.
Do you have any dietary preferences?

entries.meaning: something designed for a particular purpose.
examples: A smartphone is a very clever device that can do many different things.
The bomb disposal expert carefully disarmed the explosive device.
He invented a device to help people with disabilities to communicate.
The new kitchen is full of the latest labour-saving devices.
A compass is a simple device for finding your direction.

entries.meaning: part of a work. Repeated behaviour.
examples: The new TV drama is a six-part serial.
Charles Dickens originally published his novels as serials in a magazine.
The police are hunting for a serial killer.
You can find the serial number of the product on the back of the box.
He is a serial offender who has been in and out of prison for years.

entries.meaning: perceive a sound using your ears. (Past tense of hear).
examples: I heard a strange noise coming from outside.
Have you heard the news about the election?
She spoke so quietly that I could barely hear what she said.
He was last heard of living in Australia.
I've never heard of that author before.
He inherited a substantial amount of money from his grandfather.
The company made a substantial profit this year.
There is a substantial difference between the two proposals.
The new house is much more substantial than their old one.
She needs a substantial meal after all that exercise.

entries.meaning: to send someone for further action or review.
examples: The doctor gave me a referral to see a specialist.
We get most of our new business through referrals from existing customers.
The case was passed on to the police for referral.
You will need a referral from your GP to see a consultant.
The social worker made a referral to the child protection team.

entries.meaning: move from one place to another. (Past tense of transfer).
examples: He has been transferred to a new job in our Paris office.
The patient was transferred to a different hospital.
I transferred the money from my savings account to my current account.
The ownership of the property was transferred to the new buyer.
The data was transferred from the old computer to the new one.

entries.meaning: A member of your family or a relation.
examples: All her close kin came to the wedding.
He felt a strong sense of loyalty to his kin.
In some cultures, it is common to live with your extended kin.
He is my next of kin, so he will inherit everything I own.
The police had to inform the next of kin about the accident.

entries.meaning: A scarcity or lack of something.
examples: There is a dearth of good restaurants in this town.
The long drought led to a dearth of food in the region.
There is no dearth of information on the internet.
The team's main problem is a dearth of skilled players.
A dearth of evidence meant that the police could not press charges.
He was a jovial man who was always telling jokes.
The party was a very jovial occasion.
She was in a jovial mood and was smiling at everyone.
Our host was a jovial and welcoming person.
The jovial atmosphere in the pub made everyone feel relaxed.
They had a sumptuous meal at a very expensive restaurant.
The palace was decorated with sumptuous furnishings.
She wore a sumptuous velvet gown to the ball.
The hotel's breakfast buffet was a sumptuous feast.
He lived a sumptuous lifestyle with a private jet and a yacht.

entries.meaning: a person who changes loyalty or their mind easily.
examples: The weather is notoriously fickle at this time of year.
He is a fickle friend who will desert you when you need him most.
Public opinion can be very fickle.
The fickle football fans soon turned against their team after a few bad results.
She is very fickle and is always changing her mind about what she wants to do.

entries.meaning: Showing charm, talent. Followed by others.
examples: The politician had a great deal of charisma and was very popular with voters.
She is a very charismatic leader who inspires great loyalty.
He may not be the most handsome actor, but he has a certain charisma.
The pop star's charisma made him a favourite with the fans.
You need a lot of charisma to be a successful TV presenter.

entries.meaning: to say what will happen in the future.
examples: It is difficult to predict the weather accurately.
No one could have predicted the outcome of the election.
The company is predicting a big increase in profits this year.
She claims to be able to predict the future.
The experts predict that the new technology will change our lives.

entries.meaning: large or plump. Round or spherical.
examples: The rotund little man had a cheerful, red face.
The teapot had a pleasingly rotund shape.
He had a rotund belly that shook when he laughed.
Santa Claus is often depicted as a rotund and jolly figure.
The vase was filled with rotund, ripe tomatoes.
The weekend is a sacrosanct time for me to spend with my family.
The tradition is regarded as sacrosanct and has not been changed for hundreds of years.
The player's position in the team is not sacrosanct; he could be dropped if he doesn't play well.
The principle of free speech is not sacrosanct and has to be balanced against other rights.
For many people, their home is a sacrosanct place.

entries.meaning: to assign, divide up or share.
examples: The teacher will apportion the sweets among all the children in the class.
The blame for the accident was apportioned equally between the two drivers.
The charity will apportion the money to where it is most needed.
The land was apportioned among the farmer's three sons.
It is a difficult job to apportion the resources fairly.
He was sent to prison for tax fraud.
The company was accused of committing a massive fraud.
Be wary of emails that ask for your bank details; it could be a fraud.
She was a victim of a credit card fraud.
The police have set up a special unit to investigate online fraud.
He had a bespoke suit made by a Savile Row tailor.
The company offers a bespoke service to its clients.
She designs bespoke wedding dresses for wealthy customers.
The furniture was all bespoke and designed to fit the room perfectly.
The car has a bespoke interior made from the finest leather.
It would be churlish to refuse his generous offer of help.
He is a rather churlish man who is not very popular with his colleagues.
I thought it was very churlish of him not to say thank you.
She gave him a churlish reply and turned her back on him.
Don't be so churlish; just say you're sorry.

entries.meaning: a label/tag that stays with someone. Visible sign of illness. Also part of a flower.
examples: There is still a social stigma attached to mental illness.
He was worried about the stigma of being an ex-prisoner.
We need to remove the stigma associated with poverty.
In the past, there was a stigma attached to being a single mother.
The stigma of the disease made it difficult for him to find work.
I detest having to get up early in the morning.
The two brothers absolutely detest each other.
She detests the smell of cigarette smoke.
He detests all forms of cruelty to animals.
I detest people who are rude to waiters.

entries.meaning: courteous, kind and pleasant manner. Showing elegance.
examples: She is a very gracious hostess who always makes her guests feel welcome.
It was very gracious of him to thank me for my help.
He gave a gracious speech after winning the award.
The queen gave a gracious smile to the cheering crowd.
They live in a gracious old house in the country.
A large crowd began to congregate in the square.
The students were told not to congregate in the corridors.
The birds congregate in large flocks before migrating south.
People began to congregate around the TV screen to watch the match.
The police have the power to break up any large groups of people who congregate in the street.
He gave a supercilious smile and looked down his nose at us.
She has a very supercilious manner and treats everyone as if they are beneath her.
I found his supercilious attitude very annoying.
The waiter gave us a supercilious look when we complained about the food.
He is a supercilious and arrogant man who has very few friends.
The computer program can simulate the effects of an earthquake.
The pilots train in a flight simulator to practice for emergencies.
He simulated a fall in order to win a penalty.
The new material can simulate the feel of real leather.
The actors tried to simulate the conditions of being in a war zone.
He had the temerity to ask for a pay rise after only being in the job for a week.
She had the temerity to call the judge a fool.
No one had the temerity to question the manager's decision.
I can't believe he had the temerity to lie to my face.
He had the temerity to suggest that he was a better player than the team captain.
